I recommend getting this fun game, Supa fun to play with friends. If you've played for at least more than 55 hrs, and still would like to be acting, I think you should add 5 bucks into STE and spend it on TF2, to get premium and maybe get a few cosmetics. Anyway, love the game to bits, and

It is a well balanced game in which every class in the game has its priority and everyone has a role in the game. The only downside is the player who plays it. 
(Its either they are too good or too bad and somehow they are usually on my team @_@)
While playing this game, you will upgrade your skill and realize your mistake everytime you die. And if you die too much you can just change your class and try fighting in another way. 
The game is also free which makes it more fun (but beware , for some reason a lot of people hate p2p in here @_@) .
If you wanted to have a better experience, you can just buy any cheap item in the mann co store and have premium unlocked for free. It is a good thing that this game still thrives even today. 10/10 well thought out and very well balanced.
Would play for a long time and still not get tired of it.
This is a awesome game but there is many hackers. This game is easy when you get used to it.
Fun, insane, and many options of stuff to do. If you run out of things to do, I'd be impressed.

Very fun game for free, witha little tweaking can be ran an ony computer. Trading is a fun part of the game aswell, only downside is its a difficult game to learn with a lot of mechanics and not a very good teaching system. Have not tried the coach system,maybe i am wrong! Overall a good game in my eyes with a lot of potential, al though it has failed to reach a high point of relevancy within the past few years. Valve has recently acknowledged their lack of communication with the community,so maybe we will seemore to come to TF2 in 2017.

The game it self is a great way to pass the time, I would recommend
It to anybody who just wants to have some fun with out having to be 
Serious.

This game is well-acclaimed, and for good reason. Nine distinct classes, each with at least one role the others can't fulfill, and a signature style that brings humor to a 20th century-esque battlefield, a place where humor was simply not there. A wide variety of weapons, hats, other cosmetics, and game modes make for a new experience every time you play. Casual lets you enter a matching system that ensures you never really play the same match twice, Competitive takes it one-step further, putting you in a competitive environment, and consists of a rating system based quite heavily on performance. Mann vs. Machine is a co-op mode where you team up with other players to take down hordes of robots, with epic rewards. Community Servers let you mess around on servers hosted by the ever-loyal community, and you can even bookmark ones you like. Finally, there's Training Mode, which lets little beginners figure out what you're supposed to do, and shows FPS veterans how un-CoD-ly this game is. Not only that, but ther's also a secure, but friendly trading economy to do business with other players (there are websites and Community Servers dedicated to this). Sure, the last year of updates have been a little controversial, but the years of content before that are still here for your enjoyment. Overall, this is a wonderful game, and I think this is ideal for those into FPS, but just want to have fun.

I first downloaded this game on july, 2015. It was my first valve game, my first steam game, and also my first real computer game. I played just about every day. I went from not understanding a thing, to thinking pyro was the strongest, until hearing wm1 is trash and then figuring out that rocket jumping was a thing. I discovered the community servers button and spent time playing wacky game modes. Jailbreak, ballon races, slenderman, deathrun, and a lot more. I found out about a map called turbine and found a server close by that ran it 24/7. I played on that server almost every day until the day it closed. I met so many people that I talked to all the time and played some tf2 with. Some of them I still call my closest friends today. I listened to numerous sob stories of several veteran players, about how "it was better when I first started playing", yet they were still playing. I would even try out trading for profit. That would lead me to the unusual I still treasure to this day. I even tried my hand at non-valve competitive. There I found out the true divide between casual and comp players. I decided I would try to take it more seriously. I led a team that only won one game. (The one game that I wasn't in) I played pugs, watched streams, watched matches, practiced my movement, grinded mge, and just played n played. 

I remember the gun mettle update. "The last good one." I remember the tough break update. All the hysteria with balance changes. I remember the meet your match update, and how that "killed tf2." And finally, I remember the jungle inferno update and how it was a step in the right direction but ultimately underwhelming. 

But eventually it got to me. There comes a point where you don't put up with the crap any more. Enough was enough. I was put off by tf2 because of how much it was neglected. The lack of valve's communication, their shameful approach to their comp system, how they view community competitive tf2, and eventually my loss of interest.

Tf2 would go on to leave a sour after taste in my mouth. I liked playing it, but every time I finished playing it would spiral me further and further down into a pit of desperation. I wanted so badly for others to love tf2 as much as I did, but not even the company responsible for making this game would. 

Overall its a good game folks.
"Its like cancer attached to your bones"~Squiggy

[b]Team Fortress 2[/b] √® un FPS di cui tutti abbiamo sentito parlare; un gioco che riscosse un enorme successo, sar√† stato per la grafica cartoonesca o forse per il gameplay rapido e avvincente.
C'√® da dire che questo gioco mi conquist√≤ subito; [b] ERA [/b] il mio gioco preferito.

[h1]TF2 Ieri[/h1]
Cominciai a giocare a TF2 nell'estate del 2012, quando era gi√† Free2Play. Come "[i]beginner[/i]" non √® facile ambientarsi, ma dopo qualche mese si impara come usare le classi e sfruttare le abilit√† di ognuna di loro. 
Le 9 classi (dalle personalit√† interessanti e carismatiche) infatti permettono a ognuno di giocare secondo lo stile che preferisce. ([i]Ad esempio, se si preferisce un approccio pi√π aggressivo si sceglie una classe piuttosto che un'altra.[/i])

Le mappe sono abbastanza da rendere ogni partita diversa dalla precedente. Per quanto riguarda le armi...Beh, ce ne sono moltissime con vantaggi e svantaggi unici.

La [i]personalizzazione[/i] dei personaggi √® possibile quasi unicamente grazie allo shop dal quale comprare oggetti estetici che sono puramente decorativi, cio√® [u] non danno vantaggi[/u].
Da sottolineare che il gioco non √® assolutamente [b]Pay2Win[/b] perch√® tutte le armi si trovano giocando, anche se avere un account premium garantisce dei vantaggi in termini di "Slot di inventario".

[h1]TF2 Oggi[/h1]
Devo dire, a malincuore, che dopo pi√π di 2000 ore di gioco, TF2 mi ha abbastanza deluso.

Ci√≤ che pi√π mi ha spinto ad abbandonare (o quasi) il gioco sono gli update... incentrati sempre sull' aggiunta di nuovi cappelli, vestiti e [b]A VOLTE[/b] qualche mappa. Davvero raramente vengono introdotte nuove armi.

Se volessimo chiudere un occhio sugli aggiornamenti, non lo si pu√≤ fare per quanto riguarda il sistema anti-cheat.
Dalla mia esperienza di gioco posso dire che qualche anno fa, su 100 partite, solo in 1 o 2 c'era il solito cecchino con l'aimbot. Recentemente invece si trovano cheater molto pi√π spesso; questo problema √® aggravato inoltre dall'impossibilit√† di bannare i cheater dal server.

Infine, nell'estate del 2016, TF2 ha ricevuto "il colpo di grazia"; mi riferisco al discusso "[i]Meet your Match Update[/i]" che ha rimosso il semplice e veloce sistema di matchmaking del "vecchio" TF2 sostituendolo con uno lento e macchinoso. Il nuovo sistema di matchmaking √® stato tuttavia notevolmente migliorato con i successivi update.

[h1]Perch√® lo consiglio allora, dopo tutte le critiche che gli ho fatto?[/h1]
Perch√®, per quanto sia peggiorato, resta uno dei titoli pi√π validi di Steam e giocato con gli amici garantisce ore di risate e divertimento al modico prezzo di... ‚Ç¨ 0.00.
I HIGHLY reccomend this game. It is fun and there are many different classes, maps, and more. One can fight for hours in this game. And it's free as long as you don't buy hats.

[clop clop whinny]
  KNIGHT:  They're nervous, sire.
  ARTHUR:  Then we'd best leave them here and carry on on foot.  Dis-mount!
  TIM:  Behold the cave of Kyre Banorg!
  ARTHUR:  Right!  Keep me covered.
  KNIGHT:  What with?
  ARTHUR:  Just keep me covered.
  TIM:  Too late!
      [chord]
  ARTHUR:  What?
  TIM:  There he is!
  ARTHUR:  Where?
  TIM:  There!
  ARTHUR:  What, behind the rabbit?
  TIM:  It is the rabbit!
  ARTHUR:  You silly sod!  You got us all worked up!
  TIM:  Well, that's no ordinary rabbit.  That's the most foul, cruel,
      and bad-tempered rodent you ever set eyes on.
  ROBIN:  You tit!  I soiled my armor I was so scared!
  TIM:  Look, that rabbit's got a vicious streak a mile wide, it's a
      killer!
  KNIGHT:  Get stuffed!
  TIM:  It'll do you a trick, mate!
  KNIGHT:  Oh, yeah?
  ROBIN:  You mangy Scot git!
  TIM:  I'm warning you!
  ROBIN:  What's he do, nibble your bum?
  TIM:  He's got huge, sharp-- he can leap about-- look at the bones!
  ARTHUR:  Go on, Boris.  Chop his head off!
  BORIS:  Right!  Silly little bleeder.  One rabbit stew comin' right up!
  TIM:  Look!
      [squeak]
  BORIS:  Aaaugh!
      [chord]
  ARTHUR:  Jesus Christ!
  TIM:  I warned you!
  ROBIN:  I peed again!
  TIM:  I warned you!  But did you listen to me?  Oh, no, you knew it all,
      didn't you?  Oh, it's just a harmless little bunny, isn't it?  Well,
      it's always the same,  I always--
  ARTHUR:  Oh, shut up!
  TIM:  --But do they listen to me?--
  ARTHUR:  Right!
  TIM:  -Oh, no--
  KNIGHTS:  Charge!
      [squeak squeak]
  KNIGHTS:  Aaaaugh!  Aaaugh! etc.
  KNIGHTS:  Run away!  Run away!
  TIM:  Haw haw haw.  Haw haw haw.  Haw haw.
  ARTHUR:  Right.  How many did we lose?
  KNIGHT:  Gawain.
  KNIGHT:  Hector.
  ARTHUR:  And Boris.  That's five.
  GALAHAD:  Three, sir.
  ARTHUR:  Three.  Three.  And we'd better not risk another frontal
      assault, that rabbit's dynamite.
  ROBIN:  Would it help to confuse it if we run away more?
  ARTHUR:  Oh, shut up and go and change your armor.
  GALAHAD:  Let us taunt it!  It may become so cross that it will make
      a mistake.
  ARTHUR:  Like what?
  GALAHAD:  Well,....
  ARTHUR:  Have we got bows?
  KNIGHT:  No.
  LAUNCELOT:  We have the Holy Hand Grenade.
  ARTHUR:  Yes, of course!  The Holy Hand Grenade of Antioch!  'Tis one
      of the sacred relics Brother Maynard carries with him!  Brother Maynard!
      Bring up the Holy Hand Grenade!
      [singing]
      How does it, uh... how does it work?
  KNIGHT:  I know not, my liege.
  ARTHUR:  Consult the Book of Armaments!
  MAYNARD:  Armaments, Chapter Two, Verses Nine to Twenty-One.
  BROTHER:  "And Saint Atila raised the hand grenade up on high, saying,
      'Oh, Lord, bless this thy hand grenade that with it thou mayest blow
      thy enemies to tiny bits, in thy mercy.'  And the Lord did grin, and
      people did feast upon the lambs, and sloths, and carp, and anchovies,
      and orangutans, and breakfast cereals, and fruit bats, and large --"
  MAYNARD:  Skip a bit, Brother.
  BROTHER:  "And the Lord spake, saying, 'First shalt thou take out the
      Holy Pin.  Then, shalt thou count to three, no more, no less.  Three
      shalt be the number thou shalt count, and the number of the counting
      shalt be three.  Four shalt thou not count, nor either count thou two,
      excepting that thou then proceed to three.  Five is right out.  Once
      the number three, being the third number, be reached, then lobbest thou
      thy Holy Hand Grenade of Antioch towards thou foe, who being naughty
      in my sight, shall snuff it.'"
  MAYNARD:  Amen.
  ALL:  Amen.
  ARTHUR:  Right!  One... two... five!
  KNIGHT:  Three, sir!
  ARTHUR:  Three!
      [boom]
